text: H. Page Cross (August 23, 1910 - August 28, 1975) was an architect who practiced in New York City, active between the years 1945–1975. He was notable for having designed in the classical manner during a time when most American architects had abandoned it in favor of modernism. ==Early life and education== Page Cross was born in 1910 and grew up in New York City, the son of John Walter Cross, an architect in the firm Cross and Cross. He graduated from the Groton School (1928) Yale College (Bachelor of Arts, 1932) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Bachelor of Architecture, 1936), and served in the armed forces during World War II as a major in the Marine Corps. He worked in partnership with his father, as Cross and Son, until 1951, and after his father's death as Page Cross Architect. Cross died on August 28, 1975 at Lenox Hill Hospital, New York City, following heart surgery.The New York Times, November 6, 1975, page 22. ==Architectural works== * Music Building, Foxcroft School (completed 1948). * Schoolhouse, Foxcroft School (completed 1951). * Paul and Bunny Mellon Residence, Rokeby Road, Upperville, Virginia (completed 1951). * Paul and Bunny Mellon Residence, Oyster Harbors Island, Osterville, Massachusetts. * Trinity Episcopal Church, Upperville, Virginia (completed 1960). * Center for Hellenic Studies, Washington, DC (completed 1963). * Paul and Bunny Mellon Townhouse, 125 East 70th Street, New York City (completed 1966).Certificate of Occupancy No. 62747, February 2, 1966. * Paul and Bunny Mellon Residence, Mill Reef Club, Antigua, completed 1968. Arizona Republic, May 20, 1968, page 19. * Harding and Mary Lawrence Residence, East End Avenue, New York City (completed 1973 with Billy Baldwin).Chicago Tribune, February 28, 1973, page 49. * Southampton, NY residence (Completed 1973 with interior designer Anthony Hail)."Two For Tradition," Architectural Digest, September-October 1973. * Neil McConnell Residence, 8–12 Sutton Square, New York City (alterations 1973).Christopher Gray, "A Tiny Enclave's Changing Persona," The New York Times, October 31, 2008. ==Gallery== File:Center for Hellenic Studies.jpg|Center for Hellenic Studies, Washington, DC, completed 1963. ==External links== * ==References== Category:American Neoclassical architects Category:Yale University alumni Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni Category:1910 births Category:1975 deaths Category:Architects from New York City Category:20th- century American architects
